div.note: Padre Cristoforo arrived looking like a good captain who, through no fault of his own, had lost an important battle: distressed but not discouraged, pensive but not panicking, in a hurry but not in flight. He goes where need dictates, to protect places under siege, muster his troops, and issue new orders.
“Peace be with you,” he said as he came in.
“That man is hopeless, I’m afraid. The best we can do is trust in God, and I already have had some promise of His protection.”

None of the three, it is true, had stored much hope in Padre Cristoforo’s endeavor, since for a powerful man to desist from an act of aggression without being forced to, as a mere concession to unarmed prayers, was not only rare but unheard of. Still, this grim confirmation came as a blow to them all.
The women bowed their heads. In Renzo’s heart, anger prevailed over dejection.
Even before this announcement, he had been embittered by many painful surprises, many failed attempts, and many disappointed hopes, all of which were exacerbated, in that moment, by Lucia’s refusals.

“I’d like to know,” he shouted, gritting his teeth and raising his voice, which he had never done in Padre Cristoforo’s presence before, “what reasons that dog came up with to argue…to argue that my bride should not be my bride.”

“Poor Renzo,” the friar replied in a grave, compassionate voice and a look that ordered him, affectionately, to stay calm. “If a powerful man intent on committing an injustice always had to explain why, the world would be a different place.”
“So did that dog admit that he’s against it because he’s against it?”
“Not even that much, my poor boy.
It’d be to our advantage if, to commit the crime, he had to confess it openly.”
“But that hellhound must have said something. What did he say?”
“I heard his words, but I couldn’t repeat them to you.
The utterances of a powerful and evil man are both piercing and elusive.

He’ll fret and fume at your suspicions of him at the same time as he confirms them. He’ll insult you and say he’s offended, ridicule you and consult your opinion, terrify and whine, be rude and irreproachable.
Ask for no more details.
He did not utter this innocent girl’s name or yours. He pretended he didn’t even know you, and was not angling for anything. But…unfortunately, I got the strong sense that he will not budge.
“All the same, we must place our faith in God!
Don’t lose heart, my children. And you, Renzo…believe me when I say I put myself in your shoes, I can feel what is going through your heart.
But be patient!
Patience is a meager word, a bitter word, for non-believers. But you?…Won’t you grant God one day, two days, the time He needs to make justice triumph?
Time belongs to Him, and He has promised us eternity!
Place this matter in His hands, Renzo, and you should know…all of you should know that I’ve found a thread to help you.
That’s all I can say for now.
“Tomorrow I won’t be able to come up here. I have to be at the monastery all day, for your sake.
Renzo, try to come by. Or if for some unforeseen reason you can’t, send someone you trust, a smart boy, who can take a message back to you.
It’s getting dark. I have to run to the monastery.
Faith. Courage. God be with you.”

At this he hurried on his way, running, almost skipping, down the crooked, stony path so that he would not be late to the monastery. Otherwise he’d catch a good scolding, or worse, a penance that would keep him from being ready and able the next day to do whatever his wards might require.
“Did you hear what he said about, what did he call it…a thread that he’s found to help us?” said Lucia.
“We’d do better to trust him. When he makes a promise…”
“Is that the best he can do?” Agnese broke in.
“He should have spoken more plainly, or pulled me aside to tell me what—”
“Enough talk!” This time Renzo cut in, pacing up and down the room. “I know how to put an end to this!” His voice and expression left no doubt as to the meaning of his words.
“Oh, Renzo!” exclaimed Lucia.
“What do you mean?” exclaimed Agnese.
“Do I have to say it?
I’ll put an end to this story.
I don’t care whether he’s possessed by a hundred, a thousand demons. In the end he’s just flesh and blood.”
“No, please, for heaven’s sake!” Lucia began, but her voice was choked with tears.
“You shouldn’t say such things, even if you’re joking,” added Agnese.
“Joking?” shouted Renzo, standing directly in front of her, his eyes glaring.
“Joking? I’ll show you who’s joking.”
“Oh, Renzo,” Lucia struggled to say amid her sobs, “I’ve never seen you like this.”
“Watch your words, for heaven’s sake,” Agnese quickly repeated, lowering her voice.
“Have you forgotten how many men he has at his command?
And even if you did…God help us!…The poor can never escape justice.”
“I’ll take justice into my own hands!
It’s high time I did.
It won’t be easy, I know.
That murderous dog had better watch his back. He’s well guarded, but it doesn’t matter.
Patience and determination…and the moment will arrive.
I’ll take justice into my own hands, and rid the town of him while I’m at it. Everyone will thank me! And then, in a leap and a bound, I’ll be off to…”
Lucia’s horror at these unvarnished words stopped her weeping and gave her the strength to speak.
Lifting her tear-streaked face from her palms, she told Renzo, in a heartrending but firm voice, “So, having me for your wife no longer matters to you?
I was engaged to a God-fearing boy.
But a man who…even if he were safe from justice and vengeance, even if he were the King’s son…”
“So be it!” shouted Renzo, his face more distraught than ever. “I won’t have you, but he won’t have you, either!
I’ll be on this earth without you, and he’ll be in the devil’s…”

“No, stop. Don’t say that, for mercy’s sake. Don’t look at me like that. I can’t stand to see you this way,” Lucia exclaimed, weeping, begging with clasped hands, while Agnese kept repeating the young man’s name, over and over, rubbing his shoulders, his arms, his hands, to calm him down.

He stood there for a while without moving, lost in thought, contemplating the imploring look on Lucia’s face. Then, all of a sudden, he glared at her, took a step back, pointed his arm and index finger at his beloved, and shouted, “Her. It’s her that he wants!
I’ll kill him first!”
“And me? What did I ever do to you, for you to kill me like this?” cried Lucia, throwing herself on her knees.
“You!” he replied in a voice that expressed a different kind of anger, but anger all the same. “You!
Do you really care for me?
What proof do I have?
Haven’t I begged you, and begged you, and begged you?
And all you ever say is, ‘No, no!’ ”
“Yes, yes,” Lucia quickly replied. “I will come to the priest with you tomorrow if that’s what you want.
Go back to being the man you were. I’ll come.”
“Promise me?” said Renzo, with a voice and a face that had suddenly become more human.
“I promise.” “I’ll hold you to it.”
“The Lord be praised,” exclaimed Agnese, who was twice as happy.
In the middle of his tantrum, was Renzo calculating how to take advantage of Lucia’s fear?
Was he putting on an act to increase it, to exploit it?
Our author claims that he doesn’t know, and I’m sure not that even Renzo himself was fully aware of the answer.

The facts of the matter are that he was truly furious at Don Rodrigo, and he truly yearned for Lucia’s consent to his original plan. When two strong passions clash in a man’s heart, no one, not even the heart’s owner, can clearly distinguish one from the other, and say with certainty which of the two will prevail.
“I’ve made my promise,” Lucia replied, in a tone of shy and affectionate rebuke, “but you promised me that you’re not going to make a scene, and that you will submit to Fra Cristoforo.”
“Come now. Why do you think I lost my temper?
Do you want to go back on your promise now? And make me do something I’ll regret?”
“No, no,” replied Lucia, who was starting to grow alarmed again.
“I’ve made my promise, and I won’t go back on it.
But you have to recognize how you extracted that promise from me.
God does not wish…”
“Why do you have to be such a naysayer, Lucia?
God knows we’re not hurting anyone.”
“Promise me at least that this will be the last time we do such a thing.”
“I promise, with my heart in my hand.”
“But this time you’d better stick to it,” said Agnese.
Here the author of our manuscript admits to something else he doesn’t know: Namely, whether Lucia is truly and completely unhappy at having been forced to consent.
Like him, we will have to leave this question up in the air.

Renzo would have liked to prolong the discussion, and settle each and every detail of what they were to do the next day, but it was already dark, and the women wished him a good night, since they did not think it proper for him to linger on at that hour.
For all three, it was as rough a night as you might expect after a tumultuous and troubling day, as well as before a day destined for an important enterprise of uncertain outcome.

Renzo reappeared early in the morning and planned with the women—or rather with Agnese—the grand operation for that evening, imagining and resolving the difficulties, foreseeing setbacks, and taking turns summarizing the matter, the way you would relate a past event.
Lucia listened, and without approving in words what her heart could not accept, she promised to do her best.
“Will you be going down to the monastery to speak with Fra Cristoforo, as he asked you to last night?” Agnese asked Renzo.

“Are you crazy?” he replied. “You know what sharp eyes the friar has. He’d read my face like a book and know that something was up. And if he started asking questions, I wouldn’t come out of it very well.
Anyway, I need to stay here to take care of business.
You’d better send someone else.”
“I’ll send Menico.”
“Good idea,” replied Renzo. And he left, to take care of business, as he had put it.
Agnese went to a neighboring house to ask for Menico, a bright twelve-year-old boy who, through cousins and in-laws, had become a sort of nephew to her.
She asked his parents if she couldn’t borrow him for the day, so to speak, to run an errand, she said.
After they said yes, she took him into the kitchen, fed him breakfast, and told him to go to Pescarenico to see Padre Cristoforo, who would have a message for him to bring back when he was ready.
“Fra Cristoforo, that nice old man, you know, the one with the white beard that they call the saint…”
“I know him,” Menico said, “the one that’s always patting us children on the head, and that every now and then gives us a holy card.”
“That’s him, Menico.

And if he tells you to wait a little while, near the monastery, don’t go wandering off. Make sure that you don’t disappear with your friends to the lake, to watch the fishing, to play with the nets hung up to dry, or to play that game you like so much…”
You should know that Menico was very good at skipping stones, and we all know that everyone, old or young, is happy to do the things at which they excel. Well, and not only those.
“Come on, Auntie, I’m not a little boy.”
“Fine. Use your head. When you’re back with his message…Look here: These two brand-new coins will be for you.”
“Can’t I have them now? What difference does it make?”
“No, you’d only fritter them away.
Go now. Do a good job and there’ll be even more.”
For the remainder of that long morning, there were strange goings-on that raised no small amount of suspicion in the women’s already nervous minds.
A beggar who was neither as emaciated nor as ragged as his peers, with a somehow dark and sinister appearance, came by to beg for alms, casting furtive looks around.
He was given a piece of bread that he accepted and tucked away with barely concealed indifference.
He then lingered, with a mixture of boldness and hesitation, asking many questions to which Agnese hastened to give the wrong answers.
Then, making as if to leave, he deliberately took the wrong door, going through the one that led to the stairs, and stealing a quick look around.

When shouts followed him, “Hey! Where are you going, good man? Over this way!” he turned around and left through the exit indicated, apologizing with a meekness, an affected humility, that did not quite match the harsh features of his face.
Throughout the day, other strange figures kept appearing.
What kind of men they were, it was hard to say, though no one believed they were the honest travelers they pretended to be.

One came in on the excuse that he needed directions. Others slowed down as they passed by the front door, casting a fleeting glance through the courtyard, like a person who wants to see without being seen.
Finally, around noon, the unsettling procession came to an end.

Agnese got up every now and then, crossed the courtyard, peered out of the front gate, glanced right and then left, and came back saying, “Nobody,” a word that she uttered with relief, and that Lucia heard with equal relief, without either of them knowing exactly why.
But they both continued to feel on edge, which sapped them, especially the daughter, of much of the courage they were storing up for that evening.

The reader should know something more specific about these mysterious men lurking about. To tell the whole story, we have to retrace our steps and pay a return visit to Don Rodrigo, whom we last saw yesterday, all by himself in a hall of his palace, after the departure of Fra Cristoforo.
Don Rodrigo, as we said, was pacing back and forth in the hall, making long strides between the walls from which generations of family portraits were hung.

When he came to one wall and turned around, he found himself before an ancient warrior, a terror to both his enemies and his soldiers. He had a stern gaze, short hair standing on end, a mustache twirled into two points that protruded from his cheeks, and a slanted chin. Fully armored in greaves, cuisses, a cuirass, brassards, and gauntlets—all made of steel—the hero stood erect, right hand on his hip, left on the hilt of his sword.

Don Rodrigo stared back at him. When he turned around again, he found himself facing another ancestor, a judge, the terror of litigants and lawyers alike, seated on a big armchair upholstered in red velvet. He was ensconced in a wide robe, all black except for a white collar with two wide bands and an exposed sable lining (the distinctive uniform of senators, who only wore it in winter, which is why you never see their portraits in summer dress). His face was gaunt, his brow furrowed. In his hand he held a petition and seemed to be saying: “We shall see.”
To one side, a matron, the terror of her maids; to the other, an abbot, the terror of his monks: All people, in short, who had sown a terror that still radiated from these canvases.

In the presence of ancestors like that, Don Rodrigo became even more unsettled. He was ashamed and agitated that a friar had dared to lecture him with all the presumption of the prophet Nathan before King David.

He drew up a plan for revenge, discarded it, and pondered how he could satisfy both his passion and what he called “his honor.” At times (believe it or not), with the first words of that prophecy ringing in his ears, he could feel goosebumps, and was almost ready to give up on the idea of having his way with Lucia and the friar.
Finally, just for the sake of doing something, he called a servant, ordered him to make his excuses to the guests, saying he had been detained by an urgent matter.
When the servant came back to report that the gentlemen had left, sending their regards, Don Rodrigo, still pacing, asked, “What about Count Attilio?”
“He left with the others, my lord.”
“Good. Six men to escort me on my walk. At once!
My sword, my cloak, my hat—at once!”

The servant left, bowing in reply, and returned a few minutes later, carrying the elaborate sword, which his master buckled on; the cloak, which he threw over his shoulders; and a long-feathered hat, which he set on his head, with a fierce yank of his hand: a sign of troubled waters.
He set off and, at the door, found his six henchmen, armed and ready. They parted to let him through, bowed, and fell in behind him.
More surly, arrogant, and grumpy than usual, he left and made his way on foot to Lecco.
Seeing him arrive, the peasants and tradesmen huddled close to the walls, from where they doffed their hats and made deep bows, which he did not acknowledge.

The so-called signori also bowed, as his inferiors, since in this area, no one in a thousand miles could compete with him in name, wealth, connections, and the wish to exploit all of these to flaunt his superiority.
Them he acknowledged with a begrudging condescension.

Not on that day, but when he did happen to bump into the Spanish castellan, both parties made an equally deep bow, as was only right between two powerful men who had no dealings with each other, but, for the sake of propriety, paid homage to their respective ranks.

To chase away his foul mood, and to replace the image of the friar invading his thoughts with a completely different one, Don Rodrigo entered a house of ill repute, where he was received with the lavish and deferential cordiality accorded men who make themselves either greatly loved or greatly feared. Later that night, he returned to his palace.
Count Attilio had also just arrived back. Dinner was served, during which Don Rodrigo kept to himself and spoke very little.
“Cousin, when are you going to settle that bet?” Count Attilio teased, with a certain malice, once the table had been cleared and the servants had retired.
“It’s not the Feast of Saint Martin yet.”
“You might as well settle now. We’ll celebrate every saint’s day in the calendar before…”
“We’ll see about that.”
“Cousin, you’re playing the politician, but I can see through you. I’m so sure I’ve won our bet that I’m ready to make another.”
“Let’s hear it.”
“That padre…Padre…what’s his name? The friar, I mean. He’s converted you.”
“There you go again.”
“Converted, cousin, converted, I say.
And I’m enjoying this.
You can’t imagine how much fun it’ll be to see you contrite, with your eyes on the ground!
And what a victory for the friar.
He must have strutted home with his chest puffed out!
A fish like you doesn’t get caught every day, or with just any net.
You can be sure he’ll use you as an example. And when he gives his sermons, he’ll talk about your life.
I can almost hear him.”

Speaking through his nose and accompanying his words with exaggerated gestures, he adopted the tone of a preacher. “In that part of the world, which out of respect I shall not name, there lately lived, my dear listeners, and perhaps still does, a dissolute knight, more a friend to women than to respectable men, who, accustomed to tarring everyone with the same brush, had set his eyes…”
“Enough, enough!” interrupted Don Rodrigo, half amused and half annoyed.
“If you want to double the bet, I’m game.”
“You devil! Don’t tell me you converted the friar, instead!”
“Not another word about him. As for the bet, we’ll let Saint Martin decide.”

The count’s curiosity was aroused. He pestered Don Rodrigo with questions, but his cousin parried every single one, always deferring to the day of decision, and not wanting to reveal to his opponent plans that were neither underway nor fully settled.
The next morning Don Rodrigo woke up as Don Rodrigo again.

The dread planted in his bones by that warning, “The day will come,” had vanished together with the dreams of the night. All that remained was his anger, exacerbated by shame over his momentary weakness.
The most recent memories of his triumphal walk, the bows, the welcome, and his cousin’s teasing were of no small help in restoring his former spirits.

As soon as he rose, he sent for Griso. “Must be something big,” thought the servant who was to deliver the message, since the man bearing that nickname was none other than the chief bravo, the one who did all the dirtiest and most dangerous jobs, the master’s most trusted man, who belonged to him completely, both out of gratitude and self-interest.

After killing a man in broad daylight, and in a public square, he had gone to Don Rodrigo to beg for his protection. Don Rodrigo dressed him in his livery and shielded him from the long arm of the law.
By pledging to commit any crime he was ordered to by his new master, Griso was guaranteed impunity for that initial crime.

And for Don Rodrigo, Griso was no small acquisition. In addition to being his most valorous servant, unequaled, Griso was also living proof that his master could toy with the law as he pleased, thus increasing both the reality and the reputation of his power.
“Griso!” said Don Rodrigo. “Here’s an opportunity to prove your worth.
Before tomorrow, I want Lucia here in this palace.”
“Let it never be said that Griso refused an order from his illustrious master.”
“Take as many men as you need, assemble and order them around as you think best. So long as the outcome is good.
But above all, make sure she comes to no harm.”
“My Lord, we’ll scare her just a little, to keep her from making too much noise…there’s no way to avoid it.”
“To scare her…I know…it can’t be avoided.
But don’t touch a hair on her head. And above all, be respectful to her in every way.
Do you understand?”
“My lord, one cannot pluck a flower from the stem and present it to your Lordship without touching it.
We will do no more than necessary.”
“That will be your responsibility.
So…how do you plan to go about this?
“I was thinking, my lord.
We’re lucky her cottage is on the edge of town.

We need a place where we can meet. Not far away there’s an isolated house in the middle of the field. That house…your Lordship might not know…caught fire a few years ago, and the owners didn’t have the money to repair it, so they abandoned it. Nowadays only the witches go there. But today is not their Sabbath.

The villagers are superstitious. There’s not a night they would stop by that house for all the money in the world. But that kind of stuff makes me laugh. So we can wait there, knowing that no one will come by to spoil our plan.”
“Good. And then?”

After further proposals from Griso and objections from Don Rodrigo were voiced, the two men agreed on how to carry out the job without leaving any trace of the perpetrators; cast suspicion on others, by leaving false clues; force poor Agnese to keep her mouth shut; terrify Renzo so much that he’d forget his sorrow along with any thoughts of seeking justice or even any desire to complain; and devise all the other tricks they’d need to pull off the biggest trick of them all.

I won’t report their discussion since, as the reader will see, we don’t really need their words to understand the story. And I myself am only too happy not to waste any more time eavesdropping on the scheming of these two dastardly scoundrels.

All we need to know is that when Griso was halfway out the door, ready to set the plan in motion, Don Rodrigo called him back and said, “Listen. If that insolent jerk should happen to get in your way tonight, it wouldn’t be a bad idea to give him a few lashes on his back to remember you by.
That way we can be sure he’ll heed our warning to keep his mouth shut tomorrow.
But don’t go looking for him. I don’t want you distracted from the main goal. Do I make myself clear?”
“Leave it to me,” replied Griso, making a bow that was both obsequious and brash. And he was gone.
His morning was spent wandering about to survey the village.

That fake beggar who had infiltrated the poor little cottage was none other than Griso, who had gone in to memorize its layout. The fake wayfarers were his henchmen, who only needed a superficial knowledge of the place to execute his orders.
Having scouted the place out sufficiently, they disappeared, to avoid raising suspicions.
Back at the palace, Griso made his report and put the finishing touches on the plan. Every man was assigned his role and given instructions.
But none of this could take place without reaching the eyes and the ears of the elderly servant, who had been on the alert, realizing that something big was underway.

By gathering bits of information here and there, and deciphering an obscure word or interpreting a strange movement, he managed to piece together a clear picture of what was supposed to happen that night.
By then, however, the hour was near, and a small advance team of bravi had already gone to hide out in the ruined house.

Although the poor old man was well aware of the dangerous game he was playing, and feared arriving too late and in vain, he did not want to fail. On the excuse that he needed some fresh air, he left and made his way to the monastery, quickly quickly, to give Fra Cristoforo the promised warning.

Shortly after the old man’s departure, the remaining bravi set out, descending to the village one at a time, to avoid giving the appearance of a troop. Griso came last. The only thing left behind was a closed sedan chair, which would be taken to the abandoned house in the late evening.

Once the team had gathered at the appointed place, Griso sent three men to the village tavern. One was to station himself by the door, to observe what was happening on the street, and to see when all of the villagers had turned in for the night. The other two were to go inside to gamble and drink, like regular customers. At the same time, they were to keep an eye out, if there was indeed something to keep an eye on.
Griso, with the rest of the troop, remained in hiding.

The poor old man was still rushing to the monastery, the three bravi were reaching their post, and the sun was setting when Renzo came to the women and said, “Tonio and Gervaso are waiting for me outside. I’m going to go to the tavern with them to have a bite to eat. When the bell tolls the ‘Ave Maria,’ we’ll come by to get you.
Courage, Lucia! Timing is everything.”
Lucia sighed and repeated, “Courage,” in a voice that contradicted the word.

When Renzo and his two partners reached the tavern, they found Griso’s sentinel already at his post, taking up half the doorway, his back leaning against the frame, his arms folded across his chest. He was looking around, to the right and to the left, flashing the whites and then the blacks of his rapacious eyes.

A flat crimson velvet beret, worn at a slant, covered half his forelock. The other half was parted over his swarthy forehead, and came down under his ears on both sides, ending in braids at the nape of his neck held together by a comb.

In one hand he was holding a big cudgel, and did not seem to be carrying a more conventional weapon. From the look on his face, however, even a child would have guessed he was concealing as many weapons as humanly possible.

Renzo got to the door first; the man, without budging, stared him in the eye. But the young man, intent on avoiding any trouble, as would anyone with a tricky business at hand, pretended not to notice. He didn’t even bother to say, “Would you mind moving?” Brushing against the opposite side of the door jamb, he managed to slide sideways past that human caryatid.
His companions had to do the same.

Once inside, they saw the two bravi whose voices they had heard from outside. They were sitting at one end of the table, playing morra, both of them shouting out at the same time (as the game requires), pouring each other drinks from a big flask set between them, and making a huge racket.

They stared at the new arrivals. One of them in particular, with three grubby fingers in the air and his mouth still open from the loud “six” he had just shouted, looked Renzo up and down, from head to toe, winked at his partner, and then at the man by the door, who responded with a nod.
Renzo, unsettled and suspicious, looked at his two guests, as if hoping to find in their expressions an interpretation of these signals, but all they indicated was a hearty appetite.
The host looked at him as if awaiting their orders. Renzo drew him over to the next room and ordered their dinner.
“Who are those strangers,” he asked in a soft voice, when the host came back with a coarse tablecloth under his arm and a flask in his hand.
“I don’t know them,” replied the host as he unfolded the tablecloth.
“What, not even one of them?”
“I’m sure you know,” the man replied, smoothing the cloth on the table with both hands, “that the first rule of our trade is not to stick our nose into other people’s business. Not even our women do.
It would be begging for trouble, with so many people coming and going. It’s like a seaport in here…when the harvest is good, that is. But we keep our spirits up. The times of plenty will be back.
For us it’s enough that our customers are honest men. We don’t care who they are or aren’t. And now I’ll bring you a plate of meatballs, the likes of which you’ve never tasted.”
“How can you know…” Renzo continued, but the host was already off to the kitchen.
And there, while fetching the pan with the meatballs, one of the bravi who had been checking out our young man snuck up and asked in a whisper: “Who are those good people?”
“Decent folk from here in the village,” replied the host, while ladling the meatballs into a plate.
“Yes, but what are their names? Who are they?” the man insisted, somewhat rudely.
“One is Renzo,” the host replied, also in a whisper, “a fine young man with a good head on his shoulders. He’s a silk-worker and he’s good at what he does.
The other is a peasant named Tonio: a good lad, cheerful. Shame he hasn’t got much money, since he’d spend it all here.
The other is a half-wit, but he’s only too happy to eat whenever you put a plate in front of him.
Begging your pardon…”
He tripped as he emerged from between the stove and his questioner, and brought the plate to another customer.
“How can you be sure,” asked Renzo, picking up where he had left off when the host reappeared, “that they’re honest men if you don’t know them?”
“By their actions, my friend: You can tell a man by his actions.

Those who drink their wine without criticizing it. Pay their bill without haggling. Don’t start fights with other customers. And if they do have a jab to deliver to another, they wait outside, far from the tavern, so that the poor host doesn’t get caught in the middle. That’s what I mean by honest men.
But it’s best if you know people well, like we four know each other.
Now why in the world do you have so many questions when you’re a bridegroom, and supposed to have something else on your mind? And before a plate of meatballs that would bring the dead back to life?”
With that he returned to the kitchen.

Our author, in remarking on the different ways the host answered questions, writes that he was the type of man who always claimed to be a great friend to all good people. In practice, however, he was much more polite to those who were reputed or appeared to be thugs.
A real character, don’t you agree?
The supper was not very cheerful.

The two guests would have preferred to enjoy it at their leisure, but the man who had invited them, worried by the things the reader knows, was annoyed and even a little agitated by the odd behavior of those strangers, and could not wait to leave.
On their account, he spoke softly, in half sentences, and reluctantly.
“What a great thing,” Gervaso suddenly burst out, “that Renzo wants to get married, and needs…” Renzo gave him a dirty look.
Tonio said, “Shut up, you idiot!” accompanying the insult with a jab of his elbow.
The conversation petered out after that.
Renzo, lagging behind in his eating and drinking, was slow to refill the glasses of his two witnesses, pouring just enough to get them tipsy, but not so much as to get them drunk.

Once the table had been cleared and the bill paid by the man who had consumed the least, all three had to pass once again before those threatening faces, which turned toward Renzo, as they had when he first came in.

A few steps past the tavern, he glanced back and saw that he was being followed by the two men he had left sitting in the kitchen. So he stopped, with his friends, as if to say: “Let’s see what they want from me.”
When the two men realized they had been spotted, they also stopped, whispered to each other, and turned back.
If Renzo had been close enough to hear what they were saying, their words would have sounded very strange indeed.

“But it would be a feather in our cap, not to mention the tip you’d get,” said one of the villains, “if, back at the palace, we could tell them how we’d crushed his ribs, one-two-three, all by ourselves, without waiting for Griso’s orders.”
“And ruin the main plan?” his partner replied.
“Quick, he’s noticed something. He’s looking at us.
If only it were later!
We’d better get back, to avoid arousing suspicion.
People are still everywhere. Let’s wait till they turn in.”
They were surrounded, in fact, by the humming and buzzing you hear in a village toward evening, which just a short time later give way to the somber quiet of the night.

The women were returning from the fields, carrying their babies in their arms and leading by the hand the older children, who had been told to recite their evening prayers while they walked. The men, too, were returning, with their shovels and hoes over their shoulders.

As doors opened, you could glimpse the flickering of fires that had been lit for their humble suppers. In the street, you could hear them exchanging greetings and a word or two on the scarcity of the harvest. And above their words you could hear the regular, sonorous tolling of the bell that announced the end of the day.
Renzo saw that the two spies had retreated. He continued on his way in the growing darkness, whispering one reminder, then another, first to one brother, then to the other.
By the time they reached Lucia’s cottage, it was already night.
Between the initial conception of a dreadful deed and the acting upon it (according to a barbarian who was not devoid of genius), all the interim is like a phantasma or a hideous dream.
For hours and hours, Lucia had been lying in the grips of just such a dream. Even Agnese, the author of the plan, was lost in thought, struggling to find the words to comfort her daughter.
Yet at the moment of awakening, at the moment, in other words, for the deed to be done, the spirit finds itself wholly transformed.

The struggle between terror and courage is succeeded by a new terror and new courage: The deed enters the mind like a wholly new apparition. Sometimes the things that had seemed most frightening suddenly become easy: At other times the obstacle that had been barely noticed appears larger than ever. The imagination retreats in dismay. The limbs refuse to obey. And courage falls short of the promises it had made so confidently.

At the soft knocking of Renzo, Lucia was gripped by such terror that she resolved, at that moment, to suffer anything, to be divided from him forever, rather than go through with their plan. But when he showed his face and said, “I’m here. It’s time to go,” and with everyone else ready to set out, without hesitation, to do something that was settled and irrevocable, Lucia had neither the time nor the strength to object. With an expression as if she were being forced against her will, she took her mother’s arm, trembling, and her fiancé’s, and joined the adventurous brigade.
Quietly quietly, through the shadows and in measured steps, they left the house and took the road leading away from the village.
It would have been faster to cut across the village and go straight to Don Abbondio’s house, but they chose the long way, to avoid being seen.
Along the footpaths, through the vegetable gardens and fields, they arrived near the rectory, at which point they split up.

The two fiancés hid around the corner. Agnese stayed behind with them, but in front, so she could rush out in time to stop Perpetua and keep her occupied. Tonio was with the half-wit Gervaso, who couldn’t do anything by himself, but without whom nothing could be done. Adopting an innocent appearance, they knocked at the door.
“Who is it at this hour?” cried a voice from the window, which was flung open upon hearing the knocks. It was the voice of Perpetua.
“No one is sick, that I know of.
Has there been an accident, perhaps?”
“It’s me,” replied Tonio, “with my brother. We need to speak with the priest.”
“Is this any time for good Christians to come calling?” was Perpetua’s brusque reply.
“Where are your manners?
Come back tomorrow!”

“Listen. Maybe I’ll come back, maybe I won’t. I’ve got some money here, and I was stopping by to settle up that debt you may have heard about. I’ve got twenty-five new berlingas here. But if I can’t see him, never mind. I know where to spend my money, and I’ll come back when I’ve saved some more.”
“Wait a moment, wait. I’ll be right back.
But why are you coming at this hour of the night?”
“I just got the money a little while ago. And I thought, like I was telling you, that if I stuff it in the mattress, I don’t know how I might feel tomorrow.
But if it’s too late for you, I don’t know. Me, I’m here. If you don’t want to see me, I’ll go.”
“No, no, wait a moment. I’ll be right back with an answer.”
With these words she closed the window.

At this point Agnese broke away from the young couple. She whispered to Lucia, “Be brave. This will only take a moment. Like pulling a tooth,” and joined the two brothers by the door. She started chatting with Tonio, so that when Perpetua came to open, she would think Agnese had happened upon them by chance, and Tonio had detained her for a moment.
